lines.text: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Are you good men and true

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation, body and soul.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the princes watch.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: First, who think you the most desertless man to be constable

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole for they can write and read.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed you with a good name: to be a wellfavoured man is the gift of fortune but to write and read comes by nature.

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: Both which, master constable,

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well, for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there is no need of such vanity. You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch therefore bear you the lantern. This is your charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men you are to bid any man stand, in the princes name.

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: How if a will not stand

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go and presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God you are rid of a knave.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the princes subjects.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: True, and they are to meddle with none but the princes subjects. You shall also make no noise in the streets for, for the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: We will rather sleep than talk: we know what belongs to a watch.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman for I cannot see how sleeping should offend: only, have a care that your bills be not stolen. Well, you are to call at all the alehouses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: How if they will not

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober: if they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: Well, sir.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your office, to be no true man and, for such kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them, why the more is for your honesty.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Truly, by your office, you may but I think they that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man who hath any honesty in him.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call to the nurse and bid her still it.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child wake her with crying for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Tis very true.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: This is the end of the charge:you, constable, are to present the princes own person: if you meet the prince in the night, you may stay him.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Nay, byr our lady, that I think a cannot.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Five shillings to one ont, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not without the prince be willing for, indeed, the watch ought to offend no man and it is an offence to stay a man against his will.

lines.speaker: verges
lines.text: Byr lady, I think it be so.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there be any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep your fellows counsels and your own and good night. Come, neighbour.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here upon the churchbench till two, and then all to bed.

lines.speaker: dogberry
lines.text: One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you watch about Signior Leonatos door for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight. Adieu: be vigitant, I beseech you.
Exeunt DOGBERRY and VERGES
Enter BORACHIO and CONRADE

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: What Conrade!

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: [Aside]  Peace! stir not.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Conrade, I say!

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: Here, man I am at thy elbow.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Mass, and my elbow itched I thought there would a scab follow.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: I will owe thee an answer for that: and now forward with thy tale.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: [Aside]  Some treason, masters: yet stand close.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: Is it possible that any villany should be so dear

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villany should be so rich for when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: I wonder at it.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: Yes, it is apparel.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: I mean, the fashion.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Tush! I may as well say the fools the fool. But seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is

lines.speaker: watchman
lines.text: [Aside]  I know that Deformed a has been a vile thief this seven year a goes up and down like a gentleman: I remember his name.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Didst thou not hear somebody

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: No twas the vane on the house.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is how giddily a turns about all the hot bloods between fourteen and fiveandthirty sometimes fashioning them like Pharaohs soldiers in the reeky painting, sometime like god Bels priests in the old churchwindow, sometime like the shaven Hercules in the smirched wormeaten tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: All this I see and I see that the fashion wears out more apparel than the man. But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Not so, neither: but know that I have tonight wooed Margaret, the Lady Heros gentlewoman, by the name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress chamberwindow, bids me a thousand times good night,I tell this tale vilely:I should first tell thee how the prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: And thought they Margaret was Hero

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: Two of them did, the prince and Claudio but the devil my master knew she was Margaret and partly by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly by my villany, which did confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged swore he would meet her, as he was appointed, next morning at the temple, and there, before the whole congregation, shame her with what he saw oer night and send her home again without a husband.

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: We charge you, in the princes name, stand!

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: Call up the right master constable. We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: And one Deformed is one of them: I know him a wears a lock.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: Masters, masters,

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: Youll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: Masters,

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with us.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of these mens bills.

lines.speaker: conrade
lines.text: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, well obey you.
Exeunt
